results.title: How a Group of Female Independents Aims to Revive Australian Democracy
results.abstract: A community-driven movement has recruited around 25 candidates, most of them successful women preaching pragmatic reform. They could shape the balance of power after Saturday’s election.

multimedia.caption: Allegra Spender, an independent candidate for the Australian federal Parliament, is part of a movement aiming to save Australian democracy from the creep of corruption, right-wing populism and misogyny.
multimedia.copyright: Stephanie Simcox for The New York Times

results.title: Hooked on Cheap Oil, Hungary Resists an Embargo on Russia
results.abstract: Prime Minister Viktor Orban has promised voters to keep energy prices low. The dividends from taking Russian fuel also help fund the policies that have made Hungary a beacon for right-wing groups.
results.byline: By Andrew Higgins and Benjamin Novak

multimedia.caption: The Danube Refinery, owned by the Hungarian energy conglomerate MOL, south of Budapest. MOL said last month that it would pay out $652 million in dividends to shareholders.
multimedia.copyright: Akos Stiller for The New York Times

results.title: An Indian State Banned Alcohol. The Drinking Moved to Nearby Nepal.
results.abstract: The ban in Bihar State, championed by local women, was aimed at tackling alcoholism and domestic violence. But a drinking scene has sprung up across the border in Nepal.
results.byline: By Mujib Mashal and Bhadra Sharma

multimedia.caption: Sharing food and drinks at a bar in Mahottari, Nepal, just across the border with India.
multimedia.copyright: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times

results.title: The 17th-Century Judge at the Heart of Today’s Women’s Rights Rulings
results.abstract: Both in India and in the Roe v. Wade draft ruling roiling the United States, Lord Matthew Hale — an English judge who wrote that women were contractually obligated to husbands — still looms large.

multimedia.caption: The 17th-century English jurist Lord Matthew Hale was cited in a recent Supreme Court draft opinion that would overturn Roe v. Wade.
multimedia.copyright: Universal History Archive, via Getty Images

multimedia.caption: The 17th-century English jurist Lord Matthew Hale was cited in a recent Supreme Court draft opinion that would overturn Roe v. Wade.

results.title: Israeli Government Loses Majority, Raising Prospect of Election
results.abstract: Increasing tensions between Israeli authorities and Palestinians have put pressure on the government, leading to the possibility of a fifth election in three years.

multimedia.caption: Israel’s Parliament reopened in Jerusalem last week. A vote to bring down the government could come as early as next week.
Israel’s Parliament reopened in Jerusalem last week. A vote to bring down the government could come as early as next week.
Israel’s Parliament reopened in Jerusalem last week. A vote to bring down the government could come as early as next week.

results.title: In Ukraine, Gruesome Injuries and Not Enough Doctors to Treat Them
results.abstract: Operating with skeleton crews, doctors and nurses race to save limbs, and lives. It’s a grim routine for medical personnel often working around the clock. And not all limbs can be saved.
results.byline: By Michael Schwirtz and Lynsey Addario

multimedia.caption: Doctors trying to save a soldier’s arm in a surgery, after he was brought in earlier in the day in in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine.
Doctors trying to save a soldier’s arm in a surgery, after he was brought in earlier in the day in in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine.
Doctors trying to save a soldier’s arm in a surgery, after he was brought in earlier in the day in in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine.

results.title: A Town’s Covid Money Was Sent to One Man in Error. He Gambled It All Away.
results.abstract: An official in the rural Japanese town wired the 24-year-old man nearly $360,000 by mistake. He lost it in online casinos. Now, the town is suing and he has been arrested.
results.byline: By Hisako Ueno and Mike Ives

multimedia.caption: Abu, Japan, is about 100 miles north of the nearest major city, Fukuoka, in an area of Yamaguchi Prefecture where agriculture, fishing and forestry drive the economy.
Abu, Japan, is about 100 miles north of the nearest major city, Fukuoka, in an area of Yamaguchi Prefecture where agriculture, fishing and forestry drive the economy.

results.title: Around Kharkiv, Ukrainians Emerge to Find Lives in Ruin
results.abstract: After sheltering underground since February, residents of the beseiged city have finally been able to to assess the damage the Russians left behind. The discoveries have been grisly.

multimedia.caption: The wreckage of a market that was bombed in the Saltivka neighborhood in the eastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv.
The wreckage of a market that was bombed in the Saltivka neighborhood in the eastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv.
The wreckage of a market that was bombed in the Saltivka neighborhood in the eastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv.

results.title: Economic Headwinds Mount as Leaders Weigh Costs of Confronting Russia
results.abstract: Top economic officials are gathering this week to discuss how to keep pressure on Vladimir V. Putin without sinking their economies.
results.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Patricia Cohen

multimedia.caption: Refugees fleeing the war in Ukraine arrived in Przemsyl, Poland, in March. The conflict is taking an economic toll on Poland, which has absorbed more than three million refugees.
Refugees fleeing the war in Ukraine arrived in Przemsyl, Poland, in March. The conflict is taking an economic toll on Poland, which has absorbed more than three million refugees.
Refugees fleeing the war in Ukraine arrived in Przemsyl, Poland, in March. The conflict is taking an economic toll on Poland, which has absorbed more than three million refugees.

results.title: Strongmen in Turkey and Hungary Stall Unity in NATO and the E.U.
results.abstract: Russia benefits as Turkey slows down Swedish and Finnish applications to NATO and Hungary continues to block an E.U. embargo on Russian oil.
results.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

multimedia.caption: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has criticized Sweden as a haven for Kurdish separatists whom he sees as terrorists.
President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has criticized Sweden as a haven for Kurdish separatists whom he sees as terrorists.
President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has criticized Sweden as a haven for Kurdish separatists whom he sees as terrorists.

results.title: Selfies Further Endanger Rare Phallic Plant, Conservationists Fear
results.abstract: In Cambodia, video of women suggestively joking around with a protected carnivorous specimen prompted a government admonition: Hands off, people.

multimedia.caption: The Nepenthes gracilis, a carnivorous plant, at an exhibition in Colombia in 2018. The Nepenthes genus is distinctive for an elongated receptacle, a pitcher, with a lid that closes and trap insects inside.

The Nepenthes gracilis, a carnivorous plant, at an exhibition in Colombia in 2018. The Nepenthes genus is distinctive for an elongated receptacle, a pitcher, with a lid that closes and trap insects inside.

results.abstract: The island nation’s new prime minister revealed that the country’s economic disaster was even worse than imagined.

results.title: A Russian official tours occupied southern Ukraine.
results.abstract: The official, Marat Khusnullin, Russia’s deputy prime minister for infrastructure, outlined plans to take control of vital infrastructure.
results.byline: By Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski

multimedia.caption: A photograph taken during a trip organized by the Russian military showed Russian vehicles driving by the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Station in Enerhodar, Ukraine, this month.

results.title: The incoming U.S. ambassador to Ukraine has experience in countries shaped by Soviet domination.
results.abstract: Bridget Brink has worked in Slovakia, Uzbekistan and Georgia. She is filling a role that has been empty for three years.

multimedia.caption: Bridget Brink in Washington earlier this month during her testimony before the Senate on her nomination as ambassador to Ukraine.
Bridget Brink in Washington earlier this month during her testimony before the Senate on her nomination as ambassador to Ukraine.

results.title: The Senate overwhelmingly approves $40 billion in aid to Ukraine, sending it to Biden.
results.abstract: The measure’s relatively smooth path through Congress has reflected a broad consensus on Capitol Hill, for now, to devote massive sums to supporting Ukraine’s war effort.
results.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Catie Edmondson

multimedia.caption: A home was destroyed by Russian forces in Vilkhivka, Ukraine. The Senate gave approval to the largest foreign aid package passed by Congress in at least two decades.
multimedia.copyright: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times

results.title: Gerhard Schröder, a former German chancellor, loses perks over his ties to Russia.
results.abstract: The former German leader, a lobbyist for Russian energy companies and a friend of President Vladimir V. Putin, has declined to distance himself from Russia.

multimedia.caption: Gerhard Schöder, the former Germany Chancellor, will lose many of his post-chancellor perks after declining to distance himself from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
Gerhard Schöder, the former Germany Chancellor, will lose many of his post-chancellor perks after declining to distance himself from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

results.title: Russian soldier apologizes at war crimes trial to the widow of the man he killed.
results.abstract: Sgt. Vadim Shishimarin says he was ordered to shoot at 62-year-old Oleksandr Shelipov because he and his fellow soldiers believed that he was informing the Ukrainian military about their location.
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

results.abstract: The former monarch left his country in the wake of fraud investigations, which have since been dropped, and now lives in the United Arab Emirates.

results.title: Scientists Uncover a Shady Web of Online Spider Sales
results.abstract: More than 1,200 species of arachnids are part of a largely unregulated global marketplace, according to a new study.
org_facet: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species

results.title: The Enduring Afterlife of a Mass Shooting’s Livestream Online
results.abstract: Dozens of recordings of a 2019 massacre in Christchurch, New Zealand, remain online, in a sobering reminder of the internet’s permanence.
results.byline: By Ryan Mac, Kellen Browning and Sheera Frenkel

multimedia.caption: A memorial outside a Tops Friendly Market in Buffalo, N.Y., last weekend after a mass shooting. The gunman took inspiration from a 2019 rampage in Christchurch, New Zealand, videos of which continue circulating.
multimedia.copyright: Joshua Rashaad McFadden for The New York Times

results.abstract: The campaign detailed by a cybersecurity firm highlights Beijing’s increasingly sophisticated tactics to spy on an array of targets, including countries it considers friends.

results.title: G7 Finance Ministers Race to Secure More Ukraine Aid
results.abstract: Officials are working on a plan to provide $15 billion to help keep Ukraine’s government operating during its war with Russia.

multimedia.caption: Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal of Ukraine remotely joined a meeting of finance ministers from the Group of 7 near Bonn, Germany, on Thursday.

results.title: Boris Johnson Avoids Further Fines as the Police End Lockdown Inquiry
results.abstract: The completion of the investigation into parties at Downing Street that violated Covid rules lifts a cloud over the prime minister’s political future.
results.byline: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle

multimedia.caption: 10 Downing Street, where the British prime minister lives and works, in January. A report is expected to cast a harsh light on the alcohol-fueled culture there.

results.title: ‘Wagatha Christie’ Case Offers a Riveting Peek Into Celebrity Culture
results.abstract: Libel proceedings in London have laid bare the personal lives of two British celebrities in a legal whodunit for the social media age. And it wasn’t just the tabloids that became obsessed with the feud.

multimedia.caption: Rebekah Vardy, left, and Coleen Rooney have both leveraged their exposure as the wives of famous soccer players to build huge social media followings and become well known in their own right.

results.title: U.S. Aims to Cripple Russian Oil Industry, Officials Say
results.abstract: The revenue powers Vladimir V. Putin’s war machine in Ukraine. But plans for new U.S. sanctions could create problems with China, India and other major buyers.

multimedia.caption: Gazprom Neft’s oil refinery in Moscow. New restrictions on Russian energy sales have greater potential for long-term damage to the country’s economy.

results.title: Russia Uses Surrender in Mariupol to Portray Ukrainians as Terrorists
results.abstract: Many soldiers who surrendered from Mariupol’s Azovstal steel plant belong to the Azov battalion, a group with far-right roots, and the Kremlin may now put them on trial just as Ukraine is prosecuting Russians for war crimes.
results.byline: By Valerie Hopkins, Neil MacFarquhar, Ivan Nechepurenko and Michael Levenson
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

results.title: Biden endorses Finland and Sweden’s bids to join NATO.

results.title: A Russian soldier pleads guilty to killing a civilian and violating ‘the laws and customs of war.’
results.abstract: Sgt. Vadim Shyshimarin, 21, admitted in a Ukrainian court he had fatally shot a 62-year-old man on a bicycle in the village in the Sumy region in the early days of the invasion. He faces 10 years to life in prison.
des_facet: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
